questions.question_text: Which statement is true about internal and external LOBs?

choices.A: An external LOB can be loaded into an internal LOB variable using the DBMS_LOB package.
choices.D: After an exception transfers program control outside a PL/SQL block, all references to open external LOBs are lost.
choices.E: When using DBMS_LOB.INSTR for internal and external LOBs, DBMS_LOB.OPEN should be called for each LOB.
choices.C: Internal and external LOBs can be written using DBMS_LOB.
choices.B: A NOEXIST_DIRECTORY exception can be raised when using internal and external LOBs.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
NOEXIST_DIRECTORY: Directory does not exist
WRITE: Only internal LOBS can be written
After the exception transfers program control outside the PL/SQL program block, all references to the open BFILEs are lost. 
Only external LOBs need to be opened first, and the function to use is FILEOPEN, not OPEN.
AD correct
the only answer in the documentation is D https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E18283_01/appdev.112/e16760/d_lob.htm
I think only A is correct. Question says "which STATEMENT" (singular, so there is only 1 correct answer)
Only answer A is correct
A, D are correct

comments.content: I meant AD, not DE, for the same reason. A and D are correct.

discussion.content: AE, not DE. Only external LOBs need to be opened first, and the function to use is FILEOPEN, not OPEN.

C , E 
see here : https://docs.oracle.com/cd/B28359_01/appdev.111/b28370/inline_pragma.htm#LNPLS01362
I think answer C,E

Selected Answer: CE
https://docs.oracle.com/cd/B28359_01/appdev.111/b28370/inline_pragma.htm#LNPLS01362

comments.content:
The INLINE pragma affects only the immediately following declaration or statement, and only some kinds of statements.

When the INLINE pragma immediately precedes a declaration, it affects:

Every invocation of the specified subprogram in that declaration

Every initialization value in that declaration except the default initialization values of records

When the INLINE pragma immediately precedes one of these statements, the pragma affects every invocation of the specified subprogram in that statement:

Assignment

CALL

Conditional

CASE

CONTINUE WHEN

EXECUTE IMMEDIATE

EXIT WHEN

LOOP

RETURN

The INLINE pragma does not affect statements that are not in the preceding list.

discussion.content: Multiple pragmas can affect the same declaration or statement. Each pragma applies its own effect to the statement. If PRAGMA INLINE(subprogram,'YES') and PRAGMA INLINE(identifier,'NO') have the same subprogram, then 'NO' overrides 'YES'. One PRAGMA INLINE(subprogram,'NO') overrides any number of occurrences of PRAGMA INLINE(subprogram,'YES'), and the order of these pragmas is not important.

Selected Answer: CE
Agree with chaoyuim - CE

choices.D: Calls to TESTPROC are inlined in both lines commented as Call 1 and Call 2.
choices.A: Calls to TESTPROC will always be inlined as it is compiled with PLSQL_OPTIMIZE_LEVEL=3.
choices.E: Calls to TESTPROC might be inlined in the line commented as Call 2.
choices.B: Calls to TESTPROC are never inlined in both lines commented as Call1 and Call 2.
choices.C: Calls to TESTPROC are not inlined in the line commented as Call 1.

questions.question_text:
Examine the section of code taken from a PL/SQL program:
//IMG//

PLSQL_OPTIMIZE_LEVEL PARAMETER is set to 3.
Which two statements are true?

choices.D: It is only accessible after a grant of the CREATE PROFILE privilege.
choices.E: It helps you identify subprograms that are causing bottlenecks in application performance.
choices.B: Access it using the DBMS_HPROF package.
choices.A: Access it using the DBMS_PROFILER package.
choices.C: Profiler data is recorded in tables and published in HTML reports.

questions.question_text: Which two statements about the PL/SQL hierarchical profiler are true?

discussion.content: https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/19/adfns/hierarchical-profiler.html#GUID-B2E3A739-08C6-4648-A65F-1D093A0DADDE

comments.content:
You can use the PL/SQL hierarchical profiler to identify bottlenecks and performance-tuning opportunities in PL/SQL applications.
Stores results in database tables (hierarchical profiler tables) for custom report generation by integrated development environment (IDE) tools (such as SQL Developer and third-party tools)
The PL/SQL hierarchical profiler is implemented by the DBMS_HPROF package and has two components: Data collection, Analyzer.
Requires no special source or compile-time preparation.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BE
Package Name and Usage are correct

Selected Answer: BE
B and E
https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/ADFNS/adfns_profiler.htm#ADFNS023
This is good, B and E.
B and C?

choices.C: CREATE FUNCTION update_salary (p_nm VARCHAR2, p_sal NUMBER) RETURN PLS_INTEGER AS LANGUAGE JAVA NAME "Employee.updateSalary" PARAMETERS ("name" java.lang.String, "salary" float, RETURN int);
choices.E: CREATE FUNCTION update_salary (p_nm VARCHAR2, p_sal NUMBER) RETURN PLS_INTEGER AS LANGUAGE JAVA
choices.B: CREATE FUNCTION update_salary (p_nm VARCHAR2, p_sal NUMBER) RETURN PLS_INTEGER AS LANGUAGE JAVA NAME "Employee.updateSalary" PARAMETERS (p_nm java.lang.String, p_sal float, RETURN int);
choices.D: CREATE FUNCTION update_salary (p_nm VARCHAR2, p_sal NUMBER) RETURN PLS_INTEGER AS LANGUAGE JAVA NAME Employee.updateSalary (java.lang.String, float) return int;
choices.A: CREATE FUNCTION update_salary (p_nm VARCHAR2, p_sal NUMBER) RETURN PLS_INTEGER AS LANGUAGE JAVA LIBRARY "Employee" NAME "updateSalary" PARAMETERS (p_nm java.lang. String, p_sal float, RETURN int);

discussion.content: d is the right answer

Selected Answer: D
D is correct
Yes, Dis the correct answer since you should only point types of parameters, not their names in publication of java function.

choices.D: It will execute successfully, return the date and the DBA role will be granted to ORA1.
choices.A: It will fail with a compile-time error.
choices.B: It will execute successfully and return the date but the DBA role will not be granted to ORA1.
choices.C: It will fail with a runtime error complaining of insufficient INHERIT PRIVILEGES.

discussion.content:
https://oracle-base.com/articles/12c/control-invoker-rights-privileges-for-plsql-code-12cr1
The REVOKE statement can revoke the INHERIT PRIVILEGES privilege from a user.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct, error will only happen at runtime
Correct answer is C. Explanation is mentioned in the link shared by @DmitryPDN.
B is the correct answer

Executing SELECT return_date(1) FROM dual; gives error: ORA-00904: "RETURN_DATE": invalid identifier, because query executed in DBA_USER schema and function return_date is in ORA1 schema. Then there should be option A?

comments.content: you forgot something, return_date function is granted to PUBLIC, it's not granted directly to DBA_USER ....

discussion.content: I think the B is the correct answer, as there is an exception handler within the granting routine, which catches the privilege error at execution.

comments.content:
B is correct answer, as per your source: 
"The presence of the exception handler means regular users can run the code without noticing a difference, even though the grant would fail."
Apologies, my bad. @DmitryPDN is right. C is correct answer. in 12c Oracle added feature that throws an error in this situation

discussion.content: C is the correct answer according to this https://oracle-base.com/articles/12c/control-invoker-rights-privileges-for-plsql-code-12cr1
